titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VII:30. Saturday. Call from a person to obtain a Subscription for a new Edition of Wilson’s Ornithology. From another for a subscription for building a Church at Utica, in the State of New-York. Mr. D. Brent, about the closing business of the Session of Congress. Crafts of Vermont, to enquire when H. Allen can be despatched as Minister to Chili, and how. At the Office, W. R. King, to recommend the Mobile Argus, for printing that Laws in Alabama. Farrelly, to renew the recommendation of General Alden—to stimulate my zeal for whom he told me I had great interest in the District represented by him, Farrelly. Dodge, our Consul at Marseilles came— Is going next week for Virginia— Plumer came to agree upon arrangements for taking T. Hellen with him— After dinner; about 7. I walked up to the Capitol. P.U.S. was there— It was the last day for presenting Bills to him; but there were none ready— Hérnandez presented a full list of Members for the Legislative Council of Florida for this year. I went in to the Senate— Benton’s Western Soldiers— Went to the House— Last day Legislation— Chaotic; but quiet— No quorum— Call of the House Doors locked, and then opened— Absent members sent for— I came home after Midnight; leaving both houses sitting— They sat till near 3. A.M. Evening party.

2. VII:30— Attended Church at the Capitol— Heard Post. James 3.17. [“]But the wisdom that is from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, and easy to be intreated, full of mercy and good fruits, without partiality, and without hypocrisy.” Cushman said it might pass for a Unitarian Sermon— I called at Queen’s Hotel, to enquire of Judge Livington’s state— He is dangerously ill with a Pleurisy. His daughter just arrived— Saw judges Johnson and Duval. Visited Coll. John Taylor of Caroline S.U.S. We had D. P. Cook, Plumer, and Dodge to dine with us. Mrs Adams was ill in bed. George dined abroad. Cook came here an hour before dinner, and I had a long Conversation with him— Urged him to continue in Congress— His objections. As they went away, W. Forward, came in; and passed half an hour with me. Latter part of the Evening at Mr Brown’s of Louisiana— Small company there. Clay—His remarks on the decision of the Supreme Court, in the great Kentucky Land Cause— Judges 3 to 1. No Majority. Wants two additional judges, to constitute a special Court to try that Cause— His tones mellifluous. His enquiries concerning other public Affairs— Thomas J. Hellen came to our house to be ready to go with Mr Plumer to-morrow— I wrote to B. Abbot preceptor at Exeter; and to Plumer.

3. VII:30. Seventeenth Congress expired— Mr Burrows of Connecticut called this Morning at my house— I went to my Office, and found the President was going to the Capitol. I went with Thomas J. Hellen to Mrs. Claxton’s, and left his Trunk there; and thence to the Capitol to meet Plumer but he was gone. George and Thomas however found him; and Thomas went with him— They went from the Capitol about Noon— The President had signed all the Bills yesterday. About one, the joint Committee, Macon, and R. King of the Senate, Hill andof H.R. came into the Committee Room, and announced to the President that if he had no further Communications to make they were ready to adjourn— He said he had none and immediately afterwards went home— I went into the House, which about 2 was adjourned without day— I went in to the Supreme Court and heard Mr Emmet arguing a cause about Cross Remainders and Executory devises. Between 3 and 4 I went to my Office— Mr Blackledge of North-Carolina was there; about a claim for Sailors brought home. The Senate sat till the Evening— Negatived D. Green as Register of a Land Office in Missouri, and Vendeventer, as Navy Agent at New-York— The President renominated them, and the Senate postponed the nominations indefinitely— Evening at home; read three Acts of Hamlet to the Ladies, aloud with George. Hoarse.

4. VIII.Mr Hugh Nelson called at my House, about the preparations to be made, for his departure on his Mission to Spain— Mr John W Taylor; who goes to-morrow for home— Said if he should hear of any thing interesting at Albany he would write to me— At the Office— The Mexican Minister Zozaya, with Torrens, and Tamariz— He goes to Philadelphia, and thence to Mexico— And perhaps will return here with his family next October— Wishes to take leave of the President— C. Ruggles came and asked to see the recommendations of Beardsley, as District Attorney Northern District of N. York, as signed by New-York Members in the House. C. Pinkney came to claim an allowance for his expenses in returning to St. Petersburg. Brought an account of E. Coles as a Precedent. Captain Chauncey came, and his claim for negotiating the Algerine Treaty was settled. P.U.S. had ordered it to be allowed— James G. Forbes came for settlement of his Claims as Mayor at St. Augustine, Marshal, and Commissioner to obtain the Spanish Documents— Stone came about engraving a copper plate cypher. I was thus engaged with visitors all the morning. Dined at Mr Crawford’s with the Judges of the Supreme Court, Florida claim Commissioners and Bar— Eve at home— Read the last two Acts of Hamlet.

5. VII.Mr Daniel P. Cook called this morning, and took leave, intending to go to-morrow— Mr R. King of New-York, and Mr Van Buren were also here— At the Office— Mr Forbes came again for the Settlement of his Claims; Eldredge with Barrientos who proposes soon to return to Colombia. He offered to take despatches for me— Barrientos has some unexplained mission from Colombia. Eldredge enquired again about his own chance for an appointment as Consul of Lima— Captain Reily brought me a number of Letters of recommendation to look over. He solicits an appointment of Indian Agent— Stone came; about the engraving of a cypher plate— Mr Hernandez the Delegate from Florida, came and took leave— I called at the President’s— He appointed Friday one O’Clock, to receive the Mexican Minister— Evening at home— Mr Petry here— Mrs Hopkinson spent the day at Georgetown, but came back early in the Evening—

6. VII:30.Dr Thornton came this morning, to complain, that in the late appropriation Act, a general sum was appropriated for the Salaries of Clerks in the Department of State, including him under the general denomination of a Clerk; which he thinks a grievous disgrace— The appropriations have invariably been so for a series of years— I told the Doctor he must lay his grievance next year, before the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means who draws the Appropriation-Bill— At the Office— Diego Manzo a Chilian captured, Spanish deserting Officer came for pecuniary aid to carry him home. I could yield none— G. Blake; for an authenticated copy of an Act in favour of Captain R. Stockton— Dr Eustis to take leave. Read me a Letter to him from Tench Coxe, sent him with publications in the American Sentinel, a Philadelphia Newspaper— Eustis said the Letter was the most insidious thing he had ever received; but was just in character for the writer— F. C. Gray came to ask for a Document shewing that the Government refused to receive Onis as Spanish Minister in 1809. Gray wishes to have the St. Sebastian cases by the Florida claim Commissioners; though they have already rejected them— Calhoun came to recommend a Mr Furman, as an East-Florida Land-title Commissioner— He is urged by most of the late South-Carolina Delegation. We had company to dine. Messrs. G. Blake, Cheves, Duval, Emmet, Gray, Harper; Hoffman, Marshall, Oakley, Ogden, Sergeant, Story, Washington, Wheaton, and Winder. Coll. Dwight passed part of the Evening here— Miss Catherine Lee, was to have been married this Evening to Causici, but the match was broken off last Night.

7. VII.Keller was at my house this morning, and afterwards at the Office, with a Letter from Dr. Thornton— The Bill providing for the employment of him at the Patent Office, did not pass— G. B. English came—wishes to be employed at Constantinople— To see the President. D. Brent here— Office Affairs— At the Office— Lindsley—came to ask for employment as a Clerk— Seaton—To ask for employment for Mr Little— F. C. Gray—for the document to prove that Onis was not received as Minister of Spain in 1809. J. A. Hamilton for sundry claims in Florida— Wishes a house at St. Augustine to be taken from Rodman, and bestowed on the judge—Smith— Rhea, upon Stephen Kingston’s claim. Riley; wishes to be appointed Indian Agent at Fort Wayne— Has numerous Letters of Recommendation. H. Johnson—to recommend Cruse and White for appointments to Office. At P.U.S. Presented the Mexican Minister Zozaya, with Colonel Torrens. He is going to Philadelphia—perhaps to New-York; and thence to Mexico for his family— The President gave me the papers delivered to him by Mr Clay, and Mr Cheves, Counsel for R. W. Meade— Read them in part. Mr Lynch, Ch. Pinkney, and Addington spent the Evening here— Pleasant music.

8. VII.General Harper here; on the case of the Apollon, before the Supreme Court. Whether the Attorney General, shall be instructed to consent to an amendment of the Records to shew an appeal by the Plf on the decision of the Circuit-Court, as to the amount of the damages. I doubted the propriety of assenting to this amendment— Two men came to ask my subscription to an Edition of the Book of Common Prayer, with a Commentary by Bishop Brownell— At the Office; Dr Sewall, with Carleton of New-Hampshire applying for an appointment as a Clerk. S. Sibley the Delegate from the Michigan Territory: to take leave— C. Pinkney; to be allowed 500 dollars for his expenses in returning to St. Petersburg. And Baron Stackelberg; about the Question of discriminating duties with Norway. Promised him an answer. Drafted an answer to S. Kingston and took it to P.U.S— Also the argument of Counsel, and Memorial of R. W. Meade to the President— I told him, I would answer the Memorial in writing if he desired. He said as it was informally presented he preferred answering it in the same way himself— If Mr Clay and Mr Cheves, should wish to give it a more regular form, it might then be answered by me— Miss Hopkinson and Mary Hellen passed the Evening abroad. Dr Thornton here.

9. VI:45. To answer Letter from S. R. Bradley. Heard Little—A.M. Ephesians 5—9.10. “For the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness and righteousness and truth— Proving what is acceptable unto the Lord”—a continuation of a former Sermon, upon the morality of the Christian system— P.M. at Baker’s. Heard a Stranger. 1. Corinthians 3.11. “For other foundation can no man lay
than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ”— He addressed his auditory, as his beloved and strange friends— Coming home, I found a packet, and Note from P.U.S. calling a Cabinet Meeting, for to-morrow Noon— On the papers in R. W. Meade’s case— I sent them immediately to Mr Crawford. Mr Petry was here in the Evening— And Mrs W. S. Smith.

10. VII. Cabinet Meeting at 12. Calhoun and Thompson present. Crawford absent, unwell, and Wirt attending Supreme Court U.S— R. W. Meade’s papers— Discussion. Thompson at first inclined to think that the Commissioners ought to receive the Spanish liquidation after the signing of the Treaty, as prima facie Evidence of Meade’s claim. But he always thought the claim not included in the Treaty, and he thinks it improper that the President should interpose with the Commissioners, unless at their request. Calhoun was clear and unhesitating, that the liquidation could not be received by the Commissioners— Analogy to a cause taken out of Court and referred to arbitrators— Thompson admitted that no subsequent proceedings by one of the parties in the Court, could be admitted as evidence by the arbitrators. Conclusion, that P.U.S. should decline interposing with the Commissioners— At the Office— Rhea, about Stephen Kingston’s Letters. To call again. Rhea’s circular to his Constituents, ready— J. P. Kennedy; appointed Secretary of Legation to Chili. To know when they are to go. Ch. Pinkney here, this Eve unwell.

11. VI:45. At the Office— F. C. Gray, about the refusal to receive Onis in 1809. I declined furnishing any Document, unless called for by the Commissioners— Memorial of Clay and Rowan to the Supreme Court. H. Johnson. Going to Louisiana— Returned to him R. Kemper’s papers— Despatches from A. Gallatin, R. Rush and A. H. Everett; and many others: four hours reading. Draft of Notice to Claimants of Indemnity for lost Slaves— F. C. Gray here this Eve— Going in a day or two, for Boston.

12. VI:30.Burt here— An English Shipwright— Inventor of a Patent-sounding log; which I bought of him in England, and found not to succeed. Wants me now to recommend him here— Relation of Mr Pinkney’s— Letter to S. R. Bradley: who has honestly done me justice in answering enquiries of S. Smith. At the Office. L. Cheves—about the Slave-indemnity Commission—gave him the Documents confidential; printed by the Senate; and those relating to the negotiation of the Convention of 20. October 1818. printed for H.R.U.S. About the Secretary; and Agent— C. Pinkney—approved his account for returning to St. Petersburg, as bearer of despatches— J. P. Kennedy— Enquiries about his Office as Secretary
of Legation to Chili— Rhea: about the answer to S. Kingston— At P.U.S— Anduaga’s complaints against Captain Wilkinson— Warner’s Letters. The President sent for Secy Navy— Wilkinson to be tried, I to write to the District Attorney in Virginia to hasten the proceedings of the District judge in the case of the Ninfa Catalaña— Agent to go to Cuba. Gadsden— Difficulties of the case— Gave P.U.S. all the despatches— Lynch and C. Pinkney here this Eve— Music.

13. VII.Dr Thornton here; upon Larned’s project— At the Office; Burt with all his inventions— Asks recommendations to Commodore Rogers, and recommends his own Son in Law— Ambrose Vasse; with a resurrection of an old maritime claim of 1797. J. Sergeant with Major Hoops, an applicant for Office, in general. He had brought me a recommendation from S. Breck— Hernandez the Florida Delegate applies to have the territorial Laws printed in a Newspaper at St. Augustine. At P.U.S. Note from him— Agent to go to Cuba— Meeting appointed for to-morrow Noon. King of Frances Speech received— War between France and Spain— We had Company to dine— Caldwell, English, Gardiner, Hardin, Ives, Jaudon, W. King, Lear, M’Duffie, Pinkney, Randall, Watkins, Watts, Webster, White— Tazewell did not come— I asked Watkins to tell him I regretted the incident, at which he took offence the last time he dined here— I spoke to Webster, to engage George, as a student with him, a year from next October. Evening at Dr Lovell’s— Chess with Genl. Brown.

14. VII: Cabinet Meeting— Calhoun and Thompson present. Crawford absent unwell; and Wirt engaged in Supreme Court— War between France and Spain— What to be done?— Agent in Cuba. Hernandez— P.U.S. to see him. Calhoun’s anxiety. Information to be obtained— Consistency with what we have done to be observed. Fear of what England may do— Prospects of Spain— Danger of Treachery— Eve at home— Supper.

15. VI—James G. Forbes at the Office: about his Account and Claims— The Baron Maltitz was at my house, to announce the arrival of Baron Tuyll, the Russian Envoy, at New-York. Expects him here next week. Cabinet Meeting at 2. Calhoun and Thompson only present— Cuba— P.U.S. has seen Hernandez, who is going to the Havanna— Not as Agent— What to do? Calhoun for War with England if she means to take Cuba— Thompson for urging the Cubans to declare themselves Independent, if they can
maintain their Independence. I assume for granted that they cannot maintain their Independence, and that this Nation will not and could not prevent by War the British from obtaining possession of Cuba if they attempt to take it. The debate almost warm— Talk of calling Congress; which I thought absurd— Munm.— To be cool on this subject. Family spent the Eve at Frye’s— I at home— Assorting Documents.

16. VI:30— Heard Little. A.M. Colossians 3.16.17. “Let the word of Christ dwell in you richly in all wisdom; teaching and admonishing one another in psalms and hymns, and spiritual Songs, singing with grace in your hearts to the Lord— And whatsoever ye do in word or deed, do all in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God and the father by him.” It was a continuation of the Series of Sermons on the obligations of Christians, but with a new text, more appropriate to the special duties recommended in it— The text P.M. was Psalm 16.8. [“]I have set the Lord always before me”— Between the Services I visited Mr Edwards, Senator from Illinois; detained here by the Gout; from which he is recovering— Talk about the War between France and Spain— Cuba— Clay and his prospects— Crawford and the Banks— Ingham; the Richmond Enquirer and Virginia Times. Mr Webster dined with us— Dr Watkins here in the Evening— Has spoken to Tazewell, who is satisfied— Voluminous Mail— Reading till Midnight.

17. VI:45.Little here— Asks Letter to Dr Thornton for copies of Patents to be published— Note from P.U.S— At the Office. R. S. Coxe, with many recommendations, to be appointed Agent under the Slave Commission— Wirt to suggest G. Hay for the same appointment. Hernandez; going to the Havanna. The Spanish Documents at St. Augustine— He read the pamphlet from Cuba. Burt, about his inventions and projects— Clay to take leave. Going to Philadelphia (and to New-York). Wants a special Supreme Court U.S. to try the Kentucky Cause over again— Thinks all the present judges but one superannuated— Salvo for the Chief Justice. European Politics— Spain. Cabinet Meeting. Calhoun, Thompson, Wirt present. Crawford absent, unwell— Cuba— Meade’s information about Anduaga’s report to his Government against H. Nelson— A Letter from one Russ to Thompson. British projects upon Cuba— P.U.S. proposes to offer to G. Britain a mutual promise not to take Cuba— Objections by Calhoun and me— Thompson inclines to it— Wirt unprepared for an opinion— Calhoun thinks nothing can be obtained by it— I suppose the answer would be a proposal of guaranty to Spain, and that we should plunge into the whirlpool of European Politics. No conclusion— Eve at Genl. Brown’s— Chess.

18. VI:G. Hay called, to apply for the appointment of Agent upon the Slave-Commission. At the Office— J. Rhea—took away S. Kingston’s two Letters to him— . . .B. Colden— Application for Citizens of U.S. presented as Pirates at Portugal, for serving in Buenos-Ayres in Cruizers. James G Forbes— His claims, adjusted— Advance to him— At P.U.S. Proposed to him the appointment of G. Hay—to which he agrees— Also that C. Raguet should be employed in a political agency at Rio Janeiro, with an allowance at the rate of 1500 dollars a year. Two Notes from Anduaga— He is going to Spain— Leaves Salmon as Chargé d’Affaires— Petry and Addington here this Evening. George dined at Tayloe’s— Judge Livingston died this day.

19. VI.P.U.S. went to Loudoun— Webster and C. Pinkney, breakfasted with us, and then went with Mrs Adams, Miss Hopkinson, Mary Hellen, and George to Alexandria and Mount Vernon— G. B. English here; on his project to go to Constantinople— Mr Farnham, once of Newbury-Port; with W. Brown going to his Son, in Indiana— 33 years have furrowed his face since I saw him— Mr Gibbon of Richmond—with his wife for health. Burt the projector, who is going to Boston. Major Hoops, a Revolutionary Officer; applying for any place— At the Office. Canning— Looks very ill and has been so— Wants answers to his Notes— Slave trade especially—told him we should propose to make it piracy— Urges for the right of search— Value of Slaves carried away; not yet sent him— And when an Commissioner & Arbitrator will be ready to meet— James G. Forbe’s—going to return to New-York— Distressed for want of a place— Matthews with Van Quickenburg— Subscription for Mission among the Indians. Letter for Cardinal Gonsaloz— J. Rhea of Tennessee—returned me S. Kingston’s two Letters to him— Speculations about the Presidential Election. Means to take warm part in it— His character of J. Williams. Wrote to G. Hay—to H. Middleton, and to R. Stanard— Dined alone.— Evening, assorting papers— Waste of time.

20. V:30— Assortment of Public Documents. Drudgery. At the Office. Major Hoops came and took his papers— Mrs Hayre—pardon for her Son. Not found. G. Hay at the Office— Arrangement of papers for Slave Commissioners— Mrs AdamsMary Hellen and George returned from their party to Alexandria, and Mount Vernon— Miss Hopkinson remains at Miss Lee’s Alexandria— George unwell with a Cough.

21. VI:30.A. Van Coble, the Carpenter who built the addition to my house was here, to ask a written recommendation of him; to obtain
a job at the Navy-Yard— Mrs Hayre; for a pardon for her Son— The President’s order for it was mislaid— At the Office; Mr. J. Montgomery of Baltimore— Came to see Coll. Morrison his brother in Law, who is here lying ill— Enquired also if Mr Gallatin was coming home— Mr Rhea of Tennessee— Going next Monday— Presidential Canvas— George continues unwell— Evening Mrs Adams at her Sister Smith’s— I busied in assorting Documents— Intense labor.

22. V:30.Van Coble here— I gave him a Certificate— A man for Peter Lee; another prisoner of whom the President’s order for a pardon has been mislaid— At the Office— The pardon issued. Stackelberg came to enquire for News. Dosing. Draft to Canning— Slave-trade abolition substitute— Search for old Documents—found some— N. Edwards here this Evening— Going for Illinois— His Accounts from Albany— Mrs. Adams a part of the Eve at Dr Thornton’s. Petry here, above.

23. VI. Palm Sunday. At the Roman Catholic Church with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen— Bishop Dubourg of Louisiana, preached in English from Matthew 21.5. “Tell ye the daughter of Zion, Behold thy king cometh unto thee, meek”— His French accent is strong— His language good but not correct; his manner, animated and graceful; his style mystical, after the manner of Massillon— The previous service was a dramatized chant in Latin of the narrative of the Passion 26 and 27. Chapters of Matthew— And there was a distribution of cedar twigs for palm branches— After Church I called to see Coll. Morrison, who is confined to his bed, dangerously ill— Heard Little P.M. A Lecture instead of a Sermon. Upon the composition of the Books of the new Testament— Their Genuineness, authenticity, integrity of text— Succession of Evidence— Barnabas, Clement, Hermas, Justin Martyr, Tertullian—&c— He proposes to continue these afternoon Lectures— Webster here this Evening— Walk afterward with Mrs. Adams, George, and Mary Hellen. Still assorting Documents.

24. V:Gow here, about private property taken and carried away during the late War. P.U.S. sent me word of his return. At the Office. Draft of Note to Canning about the Slave-trade— Letter to Conard revoking the conditional pardon of Gunnell and Wood. No convicts for the Navy. At P.U.S. left with him the Slave trade Draft— Genl. Brown there— Calhoun afterwards— Read the papers about the Capture of the James Laurence by
a Porto Rico Privateer— To meet To-morrow— Judge of Supreme Court U.S. to be appointed— P.U.S. asked me to speak to S. Thompson the Secy of Navy, if he would accept it— Two brothers Van Ness recommended— Evening with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen at Thompson’s. Asked him if he would accept the appointment of judge— Rather inclines against it; but has not decided. Thinks it will not suit his health. Parish, Solomon and Bresson there— Evening party at Dr Thornton’s. George went.

25. V:30.J. Rhea of Tennessee here, and took leave. Gave me one of his circulars; Sessford called and will call again— Kankey to apply for a commercial agency at Barbadoes. Recommended by M’Kenney. A. Morrison at the Office, about his Accounts. With Documents— Cabinet Meeting. Full— Porto-Rico privateer captures— Enterprize and Hornet to be despatched— Blockade— Spanish Interdiction of trade— Porter to be sent. Answer to Canning’s Slave-trade Note— P.U.S. did not shew my draft— All agreed that we should act on the Resolution of H.R. Wirt said Spain had authorized foreign trade with her Colonies since 1811— Calhoun at the Office. Recommends Fanning as Marshal for Georgia. Draft of Letter to Secy Navy. Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George, Eve at Frye’s. I was assorting Documents.

26. V.Lowrie here to send for a modern Greek Testament to Mr Rush. English— To write me his plan; which he did— C. Pinkney at the Office, about settlement of his Accounts. At P.U.S. He was not ready with my draft to Canning upon the Slave trade— Spoke about Kankey as commercial agent at Barbadoes— Stormy day— Assorting Documents.

27. V: At the Office: Jos. Wheaton with judge Thacher of Thomastown Maine. Applying for a discharge from imprisonment of a man named Harrington. Found to have been already sent. Canning read me three Notes 1. Duke of Wellington to Montmorency; offering mediation of G.B. between France and Spain— Montmorency’s answer, declining the Mediation; and G. Canning’s reply; to it addressed to the Chargé d’Affaires of France— 16. 24 Decr. & 7. Jany. Expressed my gratification at the substance of this Correspondence. Spoke something of the Slave trade Note of the Slave-indemnity note; and of the Colonial trade Negotiation. Canning earnest about them all— Eve occupied with index to the Public Documents of the First Session 15th. Congress. Drowsy, Drudging and idle.

28. V:15.English here and at the Office— Second Letter upon his project— To call again to-morrow— Pinkney, adjusted his Accounts, and here this Evening and took leave— Lear— Claims of W. Hull as Govr of Michigan, and Brigadier General. A. Morris—Claims as Secret Agent in Spain, from 1813 to 1816— At P.U.S. with despatches from A. Gallatin and A. H. Everett— Kankey. P.U.S. thinks him too young, and declined appointing him commercial agent at Barbadoes. Miss Hopkinson returned from Alexandria, with George, who went for her. Evening absorbed still assorting Documents.

29. IV:30. Morning and Evening absorbed in assorting papers; with much waste of time. At the Office G. B. English— To prepare his Instructions as soon as possible. At P.U.S. with despatches from H. Dearborn and C. Raguet— Parish at the Office with a Note from Canning. Colonial Trade— Pressing for an Answer. Evening crazed.

30. VI— Easter Sunday. Severe storm— Rain, Hail and Snow. Went A.M. to Little’s and Baker’s— No service, at either— Day almost wholly lost in assorting papers— The further I proceed the more I find to do— Wrote Letter in the Evening to my Son John.

31. V:15. At the Office. Sent papers to the Secy of the Navy. Porto-Rico privateers— Draft of answer to Canning on the Colonial Intercourse Law— Evening again wasted in arrangement of papers— Petry here; above: Miss Hopkinson unwell.
